chapter.title: Before Using &app;
chapter.para: In this chapter, we will list a few things to think about when getting prepared to use &app; for a perfomance. First, we will list some recommended equipment. Next, we will describe some common setups. Next, we will give a summary on how to turn on the computer and test the network connection.

sect1.title: Equipment list
sect1.para: This is a quick list of the equipement used for a basic setup. Note that you need equipement on both side (local and distant.)

listitem.para: One computer, for indications on what kind of computer may be used, please refer to our Installation Manual
1 x video capture card supported under Linux.
1 x sound card
1(+) video camera(s) with A/V output.
1(+) set(s) of headphones.
1(+) microphone(s).
1 x audio mixer with at least two audio subgroups, so you can have one mix for local output and one mix to send.
Ethernet connector (10/100).
Network connection devices (hub, firewall, etc...).

sect2.para: Two groups of performance artists located in two separate venues interact directly with each other using live audio and video transmission. The performance in Room 1 is captured through cameras and microphones and sent to be broadcast in Room 2 and vice versa.

sect1.title: Connecting the devices
sect1.sect2:
Supported Devices &app; is usually used with many audio, video and MIDI devices.
It is really important to verify that you have devices that are supported by &app; and more generally by GNU/Linux. Please refer to our
Hardware Requirements page to know more about supported devices.
It is also necessary to make sure that all devices are properly configured and connected.
Here is an overview of the various peripheral used in a &app; setup and what is important to keep in mind.
Audio input
The most common audio input is a microphone. This microphone is then connected to the input of an audio mixer and then to a sound card. This Sound card is then connected to the computer. "
Audio output
The usual direct audio output is a speaker or headphones. Sometimes, there will be an audio mixer between the sound card and the actual speakers.
Video Input
The usual direct video input is a video camera. A video capture card must be used to capture a video signal if it is analog. Some USB Web camera are also supported by &app;.
Video Output
The usual direct video output is a projection screen and an control monitor.
Controll Devices

sect1.title: Turning on the computer and its devices
sect1.para: With audio and video systems, the order used to powering up each device is very important.

listitem.para: Connect only the mouse, the keyboard and the control monitor.
Connect the network cable to the network interface
Verify that you have enough power to supply your hardware. We strongly recommend the use of an UPS to regulate your power.
Power up the computer.
Verify that you log in the appropriate user session.
Verify that you are using the realtime kernel:
Type in a terminal
uname -r

You should see the -rt extension: 2.6.24-26-rt If not, you have to restart the computer. At the beginning of the reboot, you will see a grub window, press ESC and then select the kernel with the -rt extension.
Now you can turn off the computer.

Connect all the audio and video device following our
Hardware Setup page.
While connecting the device, be aware that if you have two video output, you need to connect both of the output before powering up the computer again so that both devices are detected.

Next, configure and test your audio and video following our
TestAudiovisualInputOutput page.

sect1.title: Be reached from the Internet
sect1.para: To stream with &app;, both peer must make sure their computer are reachable for the other computer. That means each peer must be able to send data to the other peer.
The easiest way to make this happen, is to have a public IP address, and all ports open to the Internet - with no firewall. An other solution would be to use a VPN.

If you are using behind a router, one thing that you can do it to configure your router to forward specific ports to the computer running &app;. The port forwarding must be done for both TCP/IP and UDP/IP on the port 17446, as well as for the whole range of 10000 to at least 11000.
The port 17446 is the communication port of &app;. &app; allocates port number from 10000 and up for the receiving streamers.

sect1.title: Testing the Devices
sect1.para: Before trying to do any live audio and video streaming, one should make sure his devices are properly pluged-in and that they are powered on. Sometimes, an audio capture card might be in the digital mode, while you would prefer to use its analog inputs. Likewise, a USB MIDI capture device might be disabled by a push button that is in the "off" position. Those things might be obvious, but they are a common source of problems.

sect1.title: Lauching the JACK Audio Server
sect1.para: If you want to stream audio, you must run the JACK audio server. There is a simple graphical user interface for JACK that is called JACK Control. You can launch it by choosing the ApplicationAudio/VideoJACK Control menu item.

sect1.title: Lauching &app;
sect1.para: To launch &app;, choose the ApplicationInternet&app; menu item. You should be ready to go!
